questiontext.text:
One other possibility that we could have, when trying to use partial fractions is where we have a repeated linear factor e.g. an expression like \(\dfrac{2x+1}{(x-1)^2}\) . Recall that the aim of the partial fractions decomposition is to arrive at a sum of terms where the numerators are constants. We can achieve this using terms with different powers of \((x-1)\) in the denominator: \[  \dfrac{2x+1}{(x-1)^2} = \dfrac{A}{x-1}+\dfrac{B}{(x-1)^2} = \dfrac{A(x-1)+B}{(x-1)^2} \] From this, we can easily find \(A\) and \(B\) so that \(A(x-1)+B=2x+1\) -- from the coefficient of \(x\) we see \(A=2\) and then looking at the constant term, we get \(B=3\). This technique works more generally. For proper rational functions with a repeated linear factor in the denominator, the partial fractions decomposition consists of terms whose denominators are powers of the linear factor. In particular: \[ \dfrac{p(x)}{(x-a)^n} = \dfrac{A_1}{x-a}+\dfrac{A_2}{(x-a)^2}+\cdots+\dfrac{A_n}{(x-a)^n} \] So for instance:

  • if the denominator has \((x-a)^2\) then we add terms \(\dfrac{A}{x-a}+\dfrac{B}{(x-a)^2}\).
  • if the denominator has \((x-a)^3\) then we add terms \(\dfrac{A}{x-a}+\dfrac{B}{(x-a)^2}+\dfrac{C}{(x-a)^3}\).
